citation.abstract: In resource-limited settings, early mortality on antiretroviral therapy (ART) is about 10% yet it is unclear how much of that mortality occurs in care or lost to follow-up. We assessed mortality rates and predictors of death among 12,222 non-pregnant ART-naïve adults initiating first-line ART between 04/2004-05/2012 in South Africa, stratified by person-years in care and lost. We found 14.6% of patients died and being lost accounted for a minority of deaths across multiple definitions of loss (population attributable-risk percent ranged from 10.4-42.5%). Although mortality rates in patients lost were much higher than in care, most ART-related mortality occurred on treatment.This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives License 4.0 (CC BY-NC-ND), which permits downloading and sharing the work provided it is properly cited. The work cannot be changed in any way or used commercially.
citation.journal: JAIDS: Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes
citation.title: Brief Report: Does Most Mortality in Patients on ART Occur in Care or After Lost to Follow-Up? Evidence From the Themba Lethu Clinic, South Africa

author.name: Journal of AIDS
author.description: JAIDS: Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes is the trusted, interdisciplinary resource for HIV- and AIDS-related information.
